pull.title: Fix waste calculation in SelectionResult
pull.body:
PR #26152 moved waste calculation into SelectionResult to be able to correct the waste score on basis of the bump_fee_group_discount for overlapping ancestries. This left two functions with largely overlapping purpose, where one was simply a wrapper of the other. This PR cleans up the overlap, and fixes the double-meaning of `change_cost` where the `GetChange()` function assumed that no change was created when `change_cost` was set to 0. This behavior was exploited in a bunch of tests, but is problematic, because a `change_cost` of 0 is permitted with custom settings for feerate and discard_feerate (i.e. when they’re both 0).

Requires #26152

tree 01c785350969802444648886de16d5c46e7c6418
parent 9b066da8af77f971046a42118fd65046321bed1b
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1684679056 -0400
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693325994 -0400

Match tx names to index in miniminer overlap test

Follow-up from #27021: In the prior commit, the vector started counting
at 0, but the transaction names started with 1. This commit matches the
names to the transactions’ vector indices for better readability.

Co-authored-by: theStack <sebastian.falbesoner@gmail.com>

tree d9ab63711004b779cf585ebca9a0570abed23c74
parent d79d62e42a41ffd571d869096b1cdba3743df004
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1686582561 -0400
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693326004 -0400

Make MiniMinerMempoolEntry fields private

Follow-up from #27021: accessing of fields in MiniMinerMempoolEntry was
done inconsistently. Even though we had a getter, we would directly
write to the fields when we needed to update them.
This commits sets the fields to private and introduces a method for
updating the ancestor information in transactions using the same method
name as used for Mempool Entries.

coinselection: Move GetSelectionWaste into SelectionResult

GetSelectionWaste will need to access more context within a selection
result, and so should be a private member function rather than a static
function. It's only use outside of SelectionResult was for tests which
have now been updated to just make a SelectionResult.

Co-authored-by: Murch <murch@murch.one>

verification.payload:
tree c39d4e94d7a92a9f89cb60129d52388bb513a937
parent 8f94d658225ba38f245c44c2c5fb5f036b89e5d3
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1667416816 -0400
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693326010 -0400

Bump unconfirmed parent txs to target feerate

When a transaction uses an unconfirmed input, preceding this commit it
would not consider the feerate of the parent transaction. Given a parent
transaction with a lower ancestor feerate, this resulted in the new
transaction's ancestor feerate undershooting the target feerate.

This commit changes how we calculate the effective value of unconfirmed UTXOs.
The effective value of unconfirmed UTXOs is decreased by the fee
necessary to bump its ancestry to the target feerate. This also impacts
the calculation of the waste metric: since the estimate for the current
fee is increased by the bump fees, unconfirmed UTXOs current fees appear less
favorable compared to their unchanged long term fees.

This has one caveat: if multiple UTXOs have overlapping ancestries, each
of their individual estimates will account for bumping all ancestors.

events.message:

When a transaction uses an unconfirmed input, preceding this commit it
would not consider the feerate of the parent transaction. Given a parent
transaction with a lower ancestor feerate, this resulted in the new
transaction's ancestor feerate undershooting the target feerate.

This commit changes how we calculate the effective value of unconfirmed UTXOs.
The effective value of unconfirmed UTXOs is decreased by the fee
necessary to bump its ancestry to the target feerate. This also impacts
the calculation of the waste metric: since the estimate for the current
fee is increased by the bump fees, unconfirmed UTXOs current fees appear less
favorable compared to their unchanged long term fees.

This has one caveat: if multiple UTXOs have overlapping ancestries, each
of their individual estimates will account for bumping all ancestors.

tree 5740ed11a10adb30b13437ccaff052397e2fe0ef
parent 526ec1ca32997a5529e20b5f687897d3de75f641
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1667841391 -0500
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693326013 -0400

Amend bumpfee for inputs with overlapping ancestry

At the end of coin selection reduce the fees by the difference between
the individual bump fee estimates and the collective bump fee estimate.

verification.payload:
tree 58d0310fe1911d492de1875ae5c5362cc8c7ec76
parent 2b01bff91fa8ab0ad4da7bce583b0ecf7870f35e
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1692646043 -0400
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693347224 -0400

Refactor ComputeAndSetWaste()

tree e453c3fd57f5c33e543c32f4ab99a8ffe4888cc0
parent 11558c4fcb5ea48df9ed17450c7ef9f19588cb38
author Murch <murch@murch.one> 1692647933 -0400
committer Murch <murch@murch.one> 1693347236 -0400

Merge GetSelectionWaste() and ComputeAndSetWaste()

Since both GetSelectionWaste() and ComputeAndSetWaste() now live in
SelectionResult, it does not make sense for one to be only a wrapper for
the other. Merges and renames the function into RecalculateWaste().

GetChange() was previously making the odd assumption that when the
`change_cost` is set to zero it means that no change is created.
However, if we build transactions at a feerate of 0 with the
discard_feerate set to zero, we'd be able to make transactions with
change that have a change_cost of zero.

This commit cleans up this duplicate meaning of change_cost and relies
on GetChange() to figure out whether there is change on basis of the
min_viable_change and whatever is left after deducting fees.

Since this broke a bunch of tests that relied on the double-use of
`change_cost` a bunch of tests had to be fixed.

events.message:
Merge GetSelectionWaste() and ComputeAndSetWaste()

Since both GetSelectionWaste() and ComputeAndSetWaste() now live in
SelectionResult, it does not make sense for one to be only a wrapper for
the other. Merges and renames the function into RecalculateWaste().

GetChange() was previously making the odd assumption that when the
`change_cost` is set to zero it means that no change is created.
However, if we build transactions at a feerate of 0 with the
discard_feerate set to zero, we'd be able to make transactions with
change that have a change_cost of zero.

This commit cleans up this duplicate meaning of change_cost and relies
on GetChange() to figure out whether there is change on basis of the
min_viable_change and whatever is left after deducting fees.

Since this broke a bunch of tests that relied on the double-use of
`change_cost` a bunch of tests had to be fixed.
